name: Emerald Tablet
shortDescription: Brief cryptic text (c. 13 lines) attributed to Hermes Trismegistus, containing the fundamental formula of alchemy and Hermetic philosophy, most famous for 'That which is below is like that which is above'
fullDescription: The Emerald Tablet (Latin: Tabula Smaragdina; Arabic: Law·∏• al-Zumurrudh) is perhaps the most influential and enigmatic text in Western esoteric tradition‚Äîa brief, cryptic formula of approximately 13 lines (varying by version) that encapsulates the entire philosophy and practice of alchemy in concentrated symbolic language. Attributed to Hermes Trismegistus and legendarily inscribed on a tablet of emerald, the text first appears in Arabic sources around 800 CE (KitƒÅb sirr al-khalƒ´qa, 'Book of the Secret of Creation' by Pseudo-Apollonius of Tyana/Balinus), then enters Latin Europe via 12th-century translations. The Tablet's most famous line‚Äî'That which is below is like that which is above, and that which is above is like that which is below, to accomplish the miracles of the one thing'‚Äîbecame the foundational principle of correspondence between microcosm and macrocosm, permeating magic, alchemy, astrology, and esoteric philosophy. The text describes the creation of all things from the One Thing (prima materia) through separation and recombination, governed by the Sun (father) and Moon (mother), carried by Wind (air), and nourished by Earth. It promises that through understanding this process, one gains 'the glory of the whole world' and conquers 'every subtle thing' and 'penetrates every solid thing.' Medieval and Renaissance alchemists interpreted the Tablet as encoding the Great Work‚Äîthe transmutation of base metals to gold and the spiritual transformation of the soul. Its influence extends from Islamic alchemy through Roger Bacon, Albertus Magnus, and Isaac Newton (who translated it multiple times) to modern occultism and New Age thought.

textStructure.form: Single brief text, highly compressed symbolic language
textStructure.length: Approximately 13 lines in most versions (varies from 12-14)
textStructure.organization: Three major sections: (1) Cosmic principle of correspondence, (2) Process of creation/transmutation, (3) Promise of power and knowledge
textStructure.standardVersion: Latin 'Vulgate' version most commonly cited (from 12th century translation)

sections.content: Declares this is truth without falsehood; all things come from the One through meditation of the One
Famous formula: 'As above, so below'‚Äîmicrocosm mirrors macrocosm
Sun is father, Moon is mother, Wind carries it, Earth nurses it; describes generation of all things from prima materia
Instructions for separating earth from fire, subtle from gross; promises supreme power and glory
This is why it's called Thrice-Great; possesses three parts of philosophy of the whole world

textStructure.variants: Arabic (earliest known), Latin (medieval), multiple Renaissance versions, Newton's translation, modern occult versions

historicalContext.earliestSource: Arabic: KitƒÅb sirr al-khalƒ´qa (Book of the Secret of Creation), c. 800 CE, attributed to Pseudo-Apollonius of Tyana (Balinus in Arabic)
historicalContext.arabicContext: Emerged in Islamic alchemical tradition blending Hellenistic philosophy, Hermetic texts, and Arabic science
historicalContext.latinTransmission: Translated into Latin 12th century (possibly by Hugo of Santalla or Plato of Tivoli) as part of Secretum Secretorum
historicalContext.medievalUse: Became foundational for European alchemy; cited by Roger Bacon, Albertus Magnus, Arnald of Villanova
historicalContext.renaissanceInterpretation: Studied intensely by Paracelsus, Giordano Bruno, Heinrich Khunrath, Michael Maier who wrote extensive commentaries
historicalContext.newtonConnection: Isaac Newton translated the Tablet multiple times (1680s), studying it as key to ancient prisca sapientia
historicalContext.legendaryOrigin: Myth claims Hermes inscribed it on emerald tablet, hidden in cave, discovered by Sarah (Abraham's wife) or Apollonius of Tyana in Hermes' tomb
historicalContext.modernRediscovery: Romantic occult revival (19th century) elevated it to supreme alchemical text; Golden Dawn and Thelema incorporated it

keyTeachings: Law of Correspondence: 'That which is below is like that which is above'‚Äîthe microcosm (individual, earth, body) mirrors the macrocosm (cosmos, heaven, spirit); understanding one reveals the other
Unity of All Things: All phenomena derive from the One Thing (prima materia, first matter); multiplicity is illusion; separation and recombination are the cosmic process
Solar-Lunar Alchemy: The Sun (gold, spirit, masculine, active) is father; Moon (silver, soul, feminine, receptive) is mother; their union generates the Philosophical Stone
Four Elements Process: The Great Work involves Wind (air, volatilization), Earth (fixation), Fire (calcination, purification), and Water (solution, dissolution)
Separation and Recombination: 'Separate the earth from the fire, the subtle from the gross'‚Äîalchemical process requires dissolution of crude matter and refinement of subtle essence
Ascent and Descent: The Stone 'ascends from earth to heaven and descends again to earth, receiving the force of things superior and inferior'‚Äîprocess of sublimation and condensation
Universal Medicine: Successful completion yields power to 'overcome every subtle thing and penetrate every solid thing'‚Äîspiritual illumination and material transmutation
Hermetic Trinity: Hermes is 'Thrice-Great' because he possesses three parts of the philosophy of the whole world (likely alchemy, astrology, theurgy or body-soul-spirit)
practicalApplications: Alchemical Laboratory Work: Blueprint for physical alchemy‚Äîdistillation, sublimation, calcination, and other operations aimed at creating Philosopher's Stone and transmuting metals
Spiritual Alchemy: Metaphorical interpretation as process of purifying the soul, separating spiritual essence from material dross, achieving enlightenment
Hermetic Meditation: Contemplation of the Tablet's verses as koan-like formulas revealing cosmic secrets through deep reflection
Talismanic Magic: Inscribing Tablet verses on talismans to channel Hermetic power; invoking correspondence principle in sympathetic magic
Astrological Alchemy: Timing alchemical operations according to planetary hours and celestial configurations based on 'as above, so below' principle
Qabalistic Interpretation: Mapping Tablet's process onto Tree of Life (descent and ascent through sephiroth; separation as differentiation of emanations)
Modern Occultism: Foundation text for Golden Dawn, Thelema, and contemporary Hermeticism; studied as key to understanding Western esoteric tradition
Psychological Alchemy: Jungian interpretation as describing individuation process‚Äîintegration of conscious and unconscious, reconciliation of opposites

renaissance.editions: Printed in countless alchemical books from 15th-18th centuries

newton.translations: Isaac Newton translated Tablet multiple times (1680s) from Latin
newton.context: Part of Newton's massive alchemical research program; sought ancient scientific wisdom
newton.manuscripts: Newton's handwritten translations preserved in Babson College collection

modern.occult: Multiple translations in 19th-20th century occult works
modern.standard: Most quoted version is composite based on medieval Latin
modern.translations: Rendered into all major European languages and beyond
